text:
Ethical principles often set a higher standard of behavior than laws and regulations.
New laws and regulations often result from recent instances of what is perceived to be
unethical behavior. Just as the Securities Act of 1933, the Glass-Steagall Act, and the
Securities Exchange Act of 1934 followed the perceived bad behavior by investment
professionals and bankers leading to the 1929 market crash, the Sarbanes-Oxley laws
followed the accounting scandals at Enron and Worldcom, and the Dodd-Frank Act
followed the 2008 financial crisis. New laws and regulations can create opportunities
for different unethical behavior. In general, ethical decisions require more judgment
and consideration of the impact of behavior on many stakeholders compared to legal
decisions.
